exercises.question: At my job, I ___ wear a uniform every day.
exercises.example_sentence: At my job, I have to wear a uniform every day, but it is comfortable.

exercises.question: Which sentence means it is 'not necessary'?
options: You mustn't go to the party.
You don't have to go to the party.
You have to go to the party.
exercises.answer: You don't have to go to the party.
exercises.example_sentence: You don't have to go to the party if you are tired.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: He has to wake up early
exercises.example_sentence: He has to wake up early to catch the train.

exercises.question: Match the situation to the correct modal.
exercises.example_sentence: I have to pay rent, but I don't have to cook every night.

exercises.question: Repeat: Do we have to leave now?
exercises.answer: Do we have to leave now?
exercises.example_sentence: The movie starts soon. Do we have to leave now?

exercises.question: She ___ study for the exam because she already passed.
exercises.example_sentence: She doesn't have to study for the exam because she already passed the test.

exercises.question: Choose the correct question form:
options: Does she have to work late?
Do she has to work late?
exercises.answer: Does she have to work late?
exercises.example_sentence: Does she have to work late tonight at the office?

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: We don't have to pay with cash
exercises.example_sentence: We don't have to pay with cash; they accept cards.

exercises.question: Match the pronoun to the correct form.
exercises.example_sentence: They don't have to wait, but she doesn't have to stay.

exercises.question: Repeat: You have to see this movie!
exercises.answer: You have to see this movie!
exercises.hint: Sometimes 'have to' is used for strong recommendations.
exercises.example_sentence: It is so funny! You have to see this movie!

exercises.question: At 8 PM last night, I ___ watching TV.
exercises.hint: Use 'was' for the first person singular.
exercises.example_sentence: At 8 PM last night, I was watching TV in the living room.

exercises.question: Which sentence describes an action in progress?
options: They were playing football when it rained.
They played football when it rained.
They are playing football when it rained.
exercises.answer: They were playing football when it rained.
exercises.hint: Use 'were' + '-ing' for a past ongoing action.
exercises.example_sentence: They were playing football when it started to rain.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: Was she working at noon yesterday ?
exercises.example_sentence: Was she working at noon yesterday?

exercises.question: Match the subject to the correct auxiliary.
exercises.hint: Think of the past of 'to be'.
exercises.example_sentence: He was eating while they were sleeping.

exercises.question: Repeat: What were you doing at ten o'clock?
exercises.answer: What were you doing at ten o'clock?
exercises.example_sentence: What were you doing at ten o'clock this morning?

exercises.question: We ___ not sleeping when the phone rang.
exercises.example_sentence: We weren't sleeping when the phone rang loudly.

exercises.question: Choose the correct spelling:
options: She was runing in the park.
She was running in the park.
She was runing in a park.
exercises.answer: She was running in the park.
exercises.example_sentence: She was running in the park when she saw a dog.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: The cat was sleeping on the sofa
exercises.example_sentence: The cat was sleeping on the sofa all afternoon.

exercises.question: Match the question to the short answer.
exercises.hint: Match the auxiliary to the subject.
exercises.example_sentence: Was it raining? No, it wasn't, it was sunny.

exercises.question: Repeat: I was driving home when I saw him.
exercises.answer: I was driving home when I saw him.
exercises.hint: Combine past continuous and past simple.
exercises.example_sentence: I was driving home when I saw him at the bus stop.

exercises.question: If it rains tomorrow, we ___ stay at home.
exercises.hint: Use 'will' for the result of a real possibility.
exercises.example_sentence: If it rains tomorrow, we will stay at home and watch movies.

exercises.question: Which sentence is a correct First Conditional?
options: If I study hard, I will pass the exam.
If I will study hard, I pass the exam.
If I study hard, I pass the exam.
exercises.answer: If I study hard, I will pass the exam.
exercises.example_sentence: If I study hard every day, I will pass the final exam.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: If you miss the bus you will be late
exercises.hint: Start with 'If' or the result clause.
exercises.example_sentence: If you miss the bus, you will be late for work.

exercises.question: Match the condition to the logical result.
exercises.example_sentence: If you eat too much cake, you will feel sick later.

exercises.question: Repeat: If I see him, I'll tell him.
exercises.answer: If I see him, I'll tell him.
exercises.example_sentence: If I see him at the office, I'll tell him the news.

exercises.question: She will be angry if you ___ late.
exercises.example_sentence: She will be very angry if you are late for the meeting.

exercises.question: What will happen if you don't wear a coat?
exercises.example_sentence: It is freezing outside; you'll get cold without a coat.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: If I have enough money I will buy a phone
exercises.example_sentence: If I have enough money, I will buy a new phone next month.

exercises.question: Match the 'If' clause to the negative result.
exercises.example_sentence: If you don't hurry up, you won't catch the last train.

exercises.question: Repeat: What will you do if it's sunny?
exercises.answer: What will you do if it's sunny?
exercises.hint: Practice the question form of the conditional.
exercises.example_sentence: What will you do if it's sunny this weekend?

exercises.question: He drives very ___; he never has accidents.
exercises.example_sentence: He drives very carefully, especially when it rains.

exercises.question: Which sentence uses the adverb correctly?
exercises.example_sentence: She speaks English well because she practices every day.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: They were talking loudly in the library
exercises.example_sentence: They were talking loudly in the library, so the librarian was angry.

exercises.question: Match the adjective to its adverb form.
exercises.example_sentence: He is a quick runner and runs quickly.

exercises.question: Repeat: Please speak slowly.
exercises.example_sentence: I don't understand; please speak slowly.

exercises.question: The children are playing ___ in their room.
exercises.example_sentence: The children are playing quietly in their room.

exercises.question: Choose the correct adverb for 'fast':
exercises.hint: 'Fast' is both an adjective and an adverb.
exercises.example_sentence: He runs very fast.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: He opened the door quietly so he wouldn't wake the baby.

exercises.question: Match the adverb to the meaning.
exercises.example_sentence: She finished the task easily.

exercises.question: Repeat: You did that very well!
exercises.example_sentence: Great job on the project; you did that very well!

exercises.question: It is raining ___, so we should stay inside.
exercises.example_sentence: It is raining hard, so we should stay inside.

exercises.question: Identify the adverb in this sentence: 'She danced beautifully.'
exercises.example_sentence: She danced beautifully at the concert.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: He finished his homework quickly so he could play.

exercises.question: Match the irregular adjectives to their adverbs.
exercises.example_sentence: He is a fast driver and drives fast.

exercises.question: Repeat: Walk carefully on the ice.
exercises.example_sentence: Walk carefully on the ice, it's very slippery.

exercises.question: The student answered all questions ___.
exercises.example_sentence: The student answered all questions correctly and got an A.

exercises.question: What is the adverb form of 'heavy'?
exercises.example_sentence: It snowed heavily all night.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.hint: Expressing an emotion through an action.
exercises.example_sentence: He looked at me sadly when I had to leave.

exercises.question: Match the adverb to its opposite.
exercises.example_sentence: He speaks loudly, but she whispers quietly.

exercises.question: Repeat: Everything will work out perfectly.
exercises.example_sentence: Don't worry; everything will work out perfectly.

exercises.question: I can't drink this tea; there is ___ sugar in it.
exercises.example_sentence: I can't drink this tea; there is too much sugar in it.

exercises.question: Which sentence is correct for a plural noun?
options: There are too much cars on the road.
There are too many cars on the road.
There are enough many cars on the road.
exercises.answer: There are too many cars on the road.
exercises.example_sentence: There are too many cars on the road during rush hour.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: I don't have enough money to buy this
exercises.hint: Enough comes after 'not have' but before the noun.
exercises.example_sentence: I don't have enough money to buy this expensive watch.

exercises.question: Match the quantifier to its use.
exercises.hint: Think about if you can count the items.
exercises.example_sentence: Too much water and too many people.

exercises.question: Repeat: Is the room warm enough?
exercises.example_sentence: It is cold outside. Is the room warm enough for you?

exercises.question: I am so tired. I didn't get ___ sleep.
exercises.example_sentence: I am so tired because I didn't get enough sleep last night.

exercises.question: Where does 'enough' go? 'This coffee is ___.'
exercises.example_sentence: This coffee is sweet enough without adding more sugar.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: There is too much noise here
exercises.example_sentence: There is too much noise here; I can't concentrate.

exercises.question: Match the problem to the quantifier.
exercises.example_sentence: The soup is bad because there is too much salt.

exercises.question: Repeat: There are too many people here.
exercises.answer: There are too many people here.
exercises.example_sentence: I want to leave because there are too many people here.

exercises.question: We have ___ food for the party, so don't buy any more.
exercises.example_sentence: We have enough food for the party, so don't buy any more.

exercises.question: Correct the error: 'He has too much tasks today.'
options: He has too many tasks today.
He has many much tasks today.
exercises.answer: He has too many tasks today.
exercises.example_sentence: He has too many tasks today to finish by 5 PM.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: This box is too heavy to carry
exercises.example_sentence: This box is too heavy to carry alone.

exercises.question: Match the opposite meanings.
exercises.hint: Focus on the scales of quantity.
exercises.example_sentence: We have too much bread, but not enough butter.

exercises.question: Repeat: I've had too much coffee.
exercises.example_sentence: I've had too much coffee and now I feel nervous.

exercises.question: Are there ___ chairs for everyone?
exercises.example_sentence: Are there enough chairs for everyone to sit down?

exercises.question: Choose the correct quantifier for 'luggage':
exercises.example_sentence: You have too much luggage for this small car.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: The shoes were not big enough
exercises.example_sentence: The shoes were not big enough for my feet.

exercises.question: Match the adjective with 'enough'.
exercises.example_sentence: He is old enough to drive a car now.

exercises.question: Repeat: Stop! That's enough.
exercises.example_sentence: Stop! That's enough sugar for one cup.

exercises.question: This phone ___ made in China.
exercises.example_sentence: This phone is made in China and exported everywhere.

exercises.question: Which sentence is in the passive voice?
options: The food is cooked by the chef.
The chef is cooking the food.
exercises.answer: The food is cooked by the chef.
exercises.example_sentence: The food is cooked by the chef every morning.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: English is spoken in many countries
exercises.example_sentence: English is spoken in many countries around the world.

exercises.question: Match the product to where it is produced (Shuffled).
exercises.hint: Match the plant to its location.
exercises.example_sentence: Rice is grown in fields, while grapes are grown in vineyards.

exercises.question: Repeat: These cars are manufactured in Germany.
exercises.answer: These cars are manufactured in Germany.
exercises.hint: Focus on the 'are' and the '-ed' sound.
exercises.example_sentence: These cars are manufactured in Germany by expert engineers.

exercises.question: Butter ___ made from milk.
exercises.example_sentence: Butter is made from milk through a simple process.

exercises.question: Choose the correct past participle for 'write':
exercises.example_sentence: The email is written in professional English.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: The rooms are cleaned every day
exercises.example_sentence: The rooms are cleaned every day by the hotel staff.

exercises.question: Match the action to the object (Shuffled).
exercises.hint: Check for singular vs plural agreement.
exercises.example_sentence: Rubbish is collected on Tuesdays, and letters are delivered daily.

exercises.question: Repeat: Is coffee grown in Brazil?
exercises.hint: Rising intonation for a passive question.
exercises.example_sentence: Is coffee grown in Brazil or in Colombia?

exercises.question: Many films ___ produced in Hollywood.
exercises.example_sentence: Many films are produced in Hollywood every year.

exercises.question: What is the passive form of 'People speak Spanish here'?
exercises.example_sentence: Spanish is spoken here by most of the locals.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: The money is kept in the bank
exercises.example_sentence: The money is kept in the bank for safety.

exercises.question: Match the participle to its base verb (Shuffled).
exercises.example_sentence: Photos are taken and gifts are given.

exercises.question: Repeat: This song is sung by millions.
exercises.answer: This song is sung by millions.
exercises.hint: Passive with 'by' to show the agent.
exercises.example_sentence: This song is sung by millions of fans.

exercises.question: Hockey ___ played on ice in Canada.
exercises.example_sentence: Hockey is played on ice in Canada during the winter.

exercises.question: Negative form: 'Newspapers ___ sold here.'
exercises.example_sentence: Newspapers are not sold here anymore; everyone reads online.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: What is plastic made of? It comes from oil.

exercises.question: Match the object to the material (Shuffled).
exercises.example_sentence: Tables are made of wood and windows are made of glass.

exercises.question: Repeat: Taxes are included in the price.
exercises.answer: Taxes are included in the price.
exercises.example_sentence: You don't need to pay extra; taxes are included in the price.

exercises.question: The Taj Mahal ___ built in the 17th century.
exercises.example_sentence: The Taj Mahal was built in the 17th century by Shah Jahan.

exercises.question: Which sentence is in the Past Passive?
exercises.example_sentence: Hamlet was written by Shakespeare around 1600.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: Penicillin was discovered in 1928 by Alexander Fleming.

exercises.question: Match the event to the year (Shuffled).
exercises.example_sentence: The Eiffel Tower was finished in 1889.

exercises.question: Repeat: My car was stolen last night.
exercises.answer: My car was stolen last night.
exercises.example_sentence: I'm so upset; my car was stolen last night.

exercises.question: The first Olympic Games ___ held in Greece.
exercises.example_sentence: The first modern Olympic Games were held in Greece in 1896.

exercises.question: Past participle for 'find':
exercises.hint: The keys were ___ in the garden.
exercises.example_sentence: The missing keys were found in the garden.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: All invitations were sent yesterday afternoon.

exercises.question: Match the inventor to the invention (Shuffled).
exercises.hint: Match the object to the creator.
exercises.example_sentence: The telephone was invented by Bell in 1876.

exercises.question: Repeat: These photos were taken in Paris.
exercises.answer: These photos were taken in Paris.
exercises.example_sentence: These photos were taken in Paris during my vacation.

exercises.question: I ___ born in 1995.
exercises.example_sentence: I was born in 1995 in a small town.

exercises.question: Negative form: 'The window ___ broken by the wind.'
exercises.example_sentence: The window wasn't broken by the wind; it was a ball.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: The shops were closed during the holiday
exercises.example_sentence: The shops were closed during the public holiday.

exercises.question: Match the base verb to its passive participle (Shuffled).
exercises.example_sentence: The bread was made and the milk was bought.

exercises.question: Repeat: When was this house built?
exercises.example_sentence: It looks very old. When was this house built?

exercises.question: The lost cat ___ found two days later.
exercises.example_sentence: The lost cat was found two days later in a park.

exercises.question: Choose the correct question:
exercises.example_sentence: Were the letters delivered this morning?

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: The wall was painted in blue
exercises.example_sentence: The wall was painted in blue last summer.

exercises.question: Match the material to the object (Shuffled).
exercises.hint: What was used to make these things?
exercises.example_sentence: Shirts were made from cotton.

exercises.question: Repeat: Mistakes were made.
exercises.example_sentence: Mistakes were made, but we will learn from them.

exercises.question: I usually ___ up at 7 o'clock every morning.
exercises.example_sentence: I usually get up at 7 o'clock every morning to exercise.

exercises.question: Which phrasal verb means 'to search for'?
exercises.example_sentence: I need to look for my glasses; I can't find them anywhere.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: Please turn off the lights when you leave the room.

exercises.question: Match the phrasal verb to its meaning (Shuffled).
exercises.hint: Think about getting dressed or undressed.
exercises.example_sentence: Put on your coat, it's cold!

exercises.question: Repeat: Can you fill in this form?
exercises.answer: Can you fill in this form?
exercises.hint: To write information on a document.
exercises.example_sentence: Can you fill in this form with your name and address?

exercises.question: Please ___ the radio; it's too loud!
exercises.example_sentence: Please turn down the radio; I'm trying to study.

exercises.question: What does 'give up' mean?
exercises.example_sentence: Learning English is hard, but don't give up.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: Please take your shoes off inside the house.

exercises.question: Match the opposite phrasal verbs (Shuffled).
exercises.example_sentence: Get on the bus and get off at the next stop.

exercises.question: Repeat: Look after your sister.
exercises.example_sentence: I'm going to the store; please look after your sister.

exercises.question: I need to ___ out what time the train leaves.
exercises.example_sentence: I need to find out what time the train leaves tomorrow.

exercises.question: Choose the correct verb: 'Please ___ up the trash.'
exercises.hint: To lift something from the floor.
exercises.example_sentence: Please pick up the trash and put it in the bin.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: Why don't you try it on ?
exercises.example_sentence: That's a nice shirt. Why don't you try it on?

exercises.question: Match the phrasal verb to the context (Shuffled).
exercises.example_sentence: Where did you grow up?

exercises.question: Repeat: Please sit down.
exercises.hint: To move from standing to a chair.
exercises.example_sentence: Please sit down and make yourself comfortable.

exercises.question: I am ___ forward to the weekend.
exercises.hint: To be excited about the future.
exercises.example_sentence: I am looking forward to the weekend because I am going to a party.

exercises.question: What does 'break down' mean for a car?
exercises.example_sentence: I was late because my car broke down this morning.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: Turn on the TV for news
exercises.example_sentence: Turn on the TV for the latest news updates.

exercises.question: Match the verb to the particle (Shuffled).
exercises.example_sentence: Wake up! You're late.

exercises.question: Repeat: Hurry up! We're late.
exercises.example_sentence: Hurry up! The taxi is waiting for us.

exercises.question: I am very ___ because the lesson is too long.
exercises.example_sentence: I am very bored because the lesson is too long and slow.

exercises.question: Which sentence is correct?
options: I am very interesting in this book.
exercises.example_sentence: This book is very interesting; I can't stop reading it.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: The movie was really frightening, so I didn't sleep well.

exercises.question: Match the feeling to the cause (Shuffled).
exercises.hint: Connect the person's feeling to the source.
exercises.example_sentence: I am tired because my work is very tiring.

exercises.question: Repeat: Are you interested in art?
exercises.example_sentence: Are you interested in art or do you prefer music?

exercises.question: The marathon was ___; everyone was exhausted.
exercises.example_sentence: The marathon was exhausting, but I finished it.

exercises.question: How do you feel before an exam?
exercises.example_sentence: I feel worried because I didn't study enough.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: I was surprised by the news
exercises.example_sentence: I was surprised by the news of her arrival.

exercises.question: Match the adjective to its effect (Shuffled).
exercises.example_sentence: This map is very confusing.

exercises.question: Repeat: That's an amazing story!
exercises.hint: The story is the cause of amazement.
exercises.example_sentence: That's an amazing story! Did it really happen?

exercises.question: I am ___ with my current job.
exercises.example_sentence: I am dissatisfied with my job because the pay is low.

exercises.question: What is the correct way to describe a loud noise?
options: I am annoying by the noise.
exercises.example_sentence: The noise from the street is very annoying at night.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: Working late every day is very tiring for the staff.

exercises.question: Match the adjective types (Shuffled).
exercises.example_sentence: Interesting books for interested people.

exercises.question: Repeat: I was shocked by the price.
exercises.answer: I was shocked by the price.
exercises.example_sentence: I was shocked by the price of that shirt!

exercises.question: It was a ___ experience for everyone.
exercises.example_sentence: It was a frightening experience when the lights went out.

exercises.question: Choose the right word: 'She was ___ to see him.'
exercises.example_sentence: She was delighted to see her old friend again.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: The instructions were very confusing, so I made a mistake.

exercises.question: Match the pair (Shuffled).
exercises.hint: Connect the feeling to the appropriate noun.
exercises.example_sentence: A relaxing afternoon makes a relaxed person.

exercises.question: Repeat: I am exhausted after work.
exercises.example_sentence: I am exhausted after work, so I'm going to sleep early.

exercises.question: The man ___ lives next door is very friendly.
exercises.example_sentence: The man who lives next door is very friendly and always says hello.

exercises.question: Which relative pronoun is used for things?
exercises.hint: The car ___ I bought is red.
exercises.example_sentence: The car which I bought last week is very fast.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: The restaurant that was famous is closed
exercises.example_sentence: The restaurant that was famous for its pizza is closed.

exercises.question: Match the noun to the correct relative pronoun (Shuffled).
exercises.example_sentence: A doctor is a person who treats people.

exercises.question: Repeat: Is that the girl who won the race?
exercises.answer: Is that the girl who won the race?
exercises.example_sentence: Is that the girl who won the race yesterday?

exercises.question: I have a book ___ is very old.
exercises.hint: 'That' can be used for people or things.
exercises.example_sentence: I have a book that is very old and rare.

exercises.question: Correct the error: 'The movie who we saw was boring.'
options: The movie which we saw was boring.
The movie where we saw was boring.
The movie that we saw was boring.
exercises.answer: The movie which we saw was boring.
exercises.hint: A movie is an object, not a person.
exercises.example_sentence: The movie which we saw last night was boring.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: I know a man who speaks five languages
exercises.hint: Relative pronoun follows the noun it describes.
exercises.example_sentence: I know a man who speaks five languages fluently.

exercises.question: Match the definition (Shuffled).
exercises.hint: Match the thing/person to their relative description.
exercises.example_sentence: A teacher is someone who helps you learn.

exercises.question: Repeat: The phone which I lost was new.
exercises.answer: The phone which I lost was new.
exercises.example_sentence: The phone which I lost was a new model.

exercises.question: She works for a company ___ makes software.
exercises.example_sentence: She works for a company which makes educational software.

exercises.question: Choose the best sentence:
options: These are the students who study hard.
These are the students which study hard.
These are the students what study hard.
exercises.answer: These are the students who study hard.
exercises.example_sentence: These are the students who study hard every day.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: The apple that I ate was sour
exercises.example_sentence: The apple that I ate for lunch was very sour.

exercises.question: Connect the halves (Shuffled).
exercises.example_sentence: I like people who are kind to others.

exercises.question: Repeat: This is the cake that I made.
exercises.answer: This is the cake that I made.
exercises.hint: 'That' is used here for a thing.
exercises.example_sentence: This is the cake that I made for your birthday.

exercises.question: Do you know anyone ___ can speak Japanese?
exercises.example_sentence: Do you know anyone who can speak Japanese fluently?

exercises.question: What pronoun for 'The cat'? 'The cat ___ is on the table is mine.'
exercises.example_sentence: The cat that is on the table is mine.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: The shoes which I bought are too small
exercises.example_sentence: The shoes which I bought online are too small.

exercises.question: Match the object to its relative pronoun (Shuffled).
exercises.example_sentence: A pilot is a person who flies planes.

exercises.question: Repeat: I don't like food that is too spicy.
exercises.answer: I don't like food that is too spicy.
exercises.hint: A preference using a relative clause.
exercises.example_sentence: I don't like food that is too spicy for my taste.

exercises.question: I have ___ friends in this city, so I'm not lonely.
exercises.example_sentence: I have a few friends in this city, so I'm not lonely.

exercises.question: Which is correct for 'time'?
options: We have a few time before the train.
We have a little time before the train.
We have many time before the train.
exercises.answer: We have a little time before the train.
exercises.example_sentence: We have a little time before the train, so let's get a coffee.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: There is a little milk left
exercises.example_sentence: There is a little milk left in the fridge.

exercises.question: Match the quantifier to the noun (Shuffled).
exercises.hint: Think about what you can count.
exercises.example_sentence: I need a few apples and a little sugar for the cake.

exercises.question: Repeat: Can I have a little water, please?
exercises.answer: Can I have a little water, please?
exercises.hint: A polite request for an uncountable item.
exercises.example_sentence: I'm very thirsty. Can I have a little water, please?

exercises.question: There are only ___ cookies left in the jar.
exercises.example_sentence: There are only a few cookies left in the jar; please buy more.

exercises.question: What is the difference between 'few' and 'a few'?
options: 'Few' is negative (not enough), 'a few' is positive (some).
'Few' is for water, 'a few' is for people.
exercises.answer: 'Few' is negative (not enough), 'a few' is positive (some).
exercises.hint: One suggests a shortage, the other a small amount.
exercises.example_sentence: He has few friends (lonely). He has a few friends (not lonely).

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: I need a little help with this
exercises.example_sentence: I need a little help with this heavy box.

exercises.question: Match the meaning (Shuffled).
exercises.example_sentence: I have little money left.

exercises.question: Repeat: I've got a few questions.
exercises.example_sentence: I've got a few questions before the meeting ends.

exercises.question: She has ___ money, so she can't buy the dress.
exercises.hint: Money is uncountable and she lacks it.
exercises.example_sentence: She has very little money, so she can't afford that dress.

exercises.question: Choose the correct sentence:
options: Add a little salt to the soup.
Add a few salt to the soup.
Add many salt to the soup.
exercises.answer: Add a little salt to the soup.
exercises.example_sentence: Add a little salt to the soup to make it taste better.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: We stayed a few days in Paris
exercises.example_sentence: We stayed a few days in Paris during our vacation.

exercises.question: Match the quantity type (Shuffled).
exercises.example_sentence: There are very few people here today.

exercises.question: Repeat: There were very few people at the party.
exercises.answer: There were very few people at the party.
exercises.example_sentence: It was quiet; there were very few people at the party.

exercises.question: Could I have ___ more coffee?
exercises.example_sentence: Could I have a little more coffee to wake me up?

exercises.question: Which word fits: 'I have ___ mistakes in my homework.'
exercises.example_sentence: I have a few mistakes in my homework, but it's okay.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: Put a bit of sugar in the tea
exercises.hint: 'A bit of' is similar to 'a little'.
exercises.example_sentence: Put a bit of sugar in the tea if it's too bitter.

exercises.question: Match the category (Shuffled).
exercises.hint: Check the -s at the end of the word.
exercises.example_sentence: I can give you a few tips and a little information.

exercises.question: Repeat: She spoke a little Spanish.
exercises.example_sentence: She spoke a little Spanish during her trip to Madrid.

exercises.question: I'm hungry! I want ___ to eat.
exercises.hint: Used in positive sentences for things.
exercises.example_sentence: I'm hungry! I want something to eat before we go out.

exercises.question: Which sentence is correct for a question?
options: Is there someone at the door?
Is there anyone at the door?
Is there no one at the door?
exercises.answer: Is there anyone at the door?
exercises.example_sentence: I heard a noise. Is there anyone at the door?

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: Nobody knows the answer to the question
exercises.example_sentence: Nobody knows the answer to that difficult question.

exercises.question: Match the pronoun to its category (Shuffled).
exercises.example_sentence: Somebody is hiding somewhere in the house.

exercises.question: Repeat: I have nothing to wear!
exercises.example_sentence: I have a party tonight but I have nothing to wear!

exercises.question: I've looked ___, but I can't find my keys.
exercises.example_sentence: I've looked everywhere, but I still can't find my keys.

exercises.question: Choose the negative sentence:
exercises.example_sentence: I don't know anyone here, so I feel a bit shy.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: There is somewhere special she is going
exercises.example_sentence: There is somewhere special she is going tonight.

exercises.question: Match the meaning (Shuffled).
exercises.example_sentence: Do you have anything? Yes, I have something.

exercises.question: Repeat: Is anyone listening to me?
exercises.example_sentence: I'm talking! Is anyone listening to me?

exercises.question: The room was empty. There was ___ there.
exercises.example_sentence: The room was empty. There was no one there when I arrived.

exercises.question: Which word fits: 'Did you go ___ interesting?'
exercises.example_sentence: Did you go anywhere interesting during your holiday?

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: There is something in my bag
exercises.example_sentence: There is something heavy in my bag.

exercises.question: Match the opposite (Shuffled).
exercises.example_sentence: Everyone likes music, but no one likes noise.

exercises.question: Repeat: Everything is going to be okay.
exercises.answer: Everything is going to be okay.
exercises.example_sentence: Don't worry, everything is going to be okay.

exercises.question: I'm bored. There is ___ to do in this town.
exercises.example_sentence: I'm bored. There is nothing to do in this town on Sundays.

exercises.question: Choose the correct phrase:
options: No one told me about it (it's a secret).
exercises.hint: An unknown person did the action.
exercises.example_sentence: Someone told me about the new restaurant, but I forgot who.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: I lost my pen and I can't find it anywhere.

exercises.question: Match the pronoun to the context (Shuffled).
exercises.hint: Pronouns are often followed by adjectives.
exercises.example_sentence: I want something sweet after dinner.

exercises.question: Repeat: Somebody help me!
exercises.example_sentence: I'm stuck! Somebody help me!
